Authors:
Krystle Angelique Aguda Santiago, Thomas Edison Espinoza
dela Cruz, Adeline Su Yien Ting
Title:
Revealing the diversity and bioactivities of culturable
endolichenic fungi from fruticose lichens: a case study of Usnea in
Bukit Larut, Malaysia
Abstract:
Endolichenc fungi (ELF) are a group of organisms
inhabiting lichens. In this study, ELF were isolated from three common
Usnea lichens, namely U. baileyi, U. bismolliuscula and U. pectinata,
all collected from Bukit Larut, Malaysia. A total of 84 ELF were
isolated, and taxonomic analysis revealed they belonged to
Sordariomycetes (representing 10 genera), primarily species of the genus
Nemania (45%, 28 ELF), and Xylaria (26%, 16 ELF), while Annulohypoxylon,
Daldinia, Hyoxylon and Pseudopestalotiopsis are the rare genera (<
2%). The ELF colonization, abundance and diversity could be best
described as the consequence of the interplay of elevation, climate and
lichen host. Our results agree well with the hypothesis that lichens
serve as a potential cradle for fungal diversity and lifestyle
evolution, particularly on the isolation of fungi previously reported as
plant endophytes and the discovery of Pseudopestalotiopsis theae (from
U. pectinata) as ELF for the first time. Results also revealed that most
lichen crude extracts were active against Gram-positive bacterium (e.g.,
Staphylococcus aureus) while ELF, particularly P. theae, were effective
against both Gram-positive (S. aureus) and Gram-negative (Escherichia
coli) bacteria, revealing the advantage of ELF over lichen crude
extracts. In addition, the higher total flavonoid content (TFC) and
antioxidant activities of ELF have revealed its antioxidant potential.
ELF could therefore be a significant alternative to drug discovery.
Although some fastidious species may have possibly been excluded due to
isolation method, this study has provided the first evaluation of the
diversity and bioactivities of culturable ELF from Usnea in Bukit, Larut
Malaysia.
